column3:
> [ee722d3](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/ee722d3fdb16b374197fd80ad564146e7eff524e): It's not clear what this commit is doing, or what `Align frameworks with macOS codesign tool requirements` is meant to mean.

Yeah, it was a hard time for me to choose a right wording. Without the first commit the signing tool returns an error:
```
% make deploy
...
dist/Bitcoin-Qt.app: rep

> Yeah, it was a hard time for me to choose a right wording. Without the first commit the signing tool returns an error:\n\nOk. I'll have a look. This needs a better commit message (with explanation), otherwise by itself, it's not clear what problem it's fixing or why it's the correct solution.

Tested on macOS 11.4 (20F71)

![Remote Desktop Picture August 11, 2021 at 12 53 52 AM EDT](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/128971628-ff69d244-2b8d-4f7c-bb51-c93b43807fec.png)

--- 

Note:

Technically the package import order is not standard.
This may be a good time to bring it into compliance.

https://github.com/RandyMcMillan/bitcoin/commit/d8deef3b9176c26a

Updated bbdd5889da71955e8004b43217b740ddaf799d4e -> 462e63220867982495804397beb782ebc0b2e17a ([pr22546.03](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr22546.03) -> [pr22546.04](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr22546.04)):

- addressed @jarolrod's [comment](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22546#discussion_r702340406)
- rebased on the recent CI code

Updated 462e63220867982495804397beb782ebc0b2e17a -> c206adc4a304c85cfaeb67eeea38dd8c0409ed95 ([pr22546.04](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr22546.04) -> [pr22546.05](https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/pr22546.05)):

- addressed @fanquake's [comment](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22546#discussion_r679617499):
> Probably easier to just always sign then. Otherwise

tACK c206adc


![Remote Desktop Picture September 22, 2021 at 4 13 22 PM EDT](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/152159/134415767-3a7fbad9-4628-4ba1-a3bf-0dbcbf2ba76b.png)
Is there a problem with just always signing in the `need_to_sign_target` case,  i.e non-depends builds, rather than making this specific to arm64?
Not a problem at all, just not required.
Probably easier to just always sign then. Otherwise this should have an explainer.

Is the following comment good as an explanation (compiled from Apple [docs](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/macos-release-notes/macos-big-sur-11_0_1-universal-apps-release-notes)):\n\n_"In macOS 11 on Macs with Apple silicon the operating system enforces that any executable must be signed before itâ€™s allowed to run. After using tools such as strip or install_name_tool, to call codesign
I agree that adding a comment here makes sense. It's not obvious why this would be ARM-only.
It's kind of ugly to use a global here, can't we return the flag in DeploymentInfo.

I am of the opinion that it is just easier to always sign. Right now the requirement is only for apple silicon, but I have not seen anything to say that this wouldn't expand to remaining intel Macs in future OS versions.

If we stick with only signing for arm, then the following is a suitable comment:

> "Starting with macOS 11 on Apple silicon, executables must be signed before they are a
> Probably easier to just always sign then. Otherwise this should have an explainer.\n\n[Updated](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/22546#issuecomment-919073042).
